item.title: After 50 Years in the Shadows, a Tenacious First-Time Novelist Steps Out Front
item.description: For 50 years, Patricia Finn kept to the background and told other people’s stories. Now, in “The Golden Boy,” she’s finally telling one of her own.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Life does have a way of rearranging your plans,” says Patricia Finn, in her Vancouver home,

item.title: Picture Books and Graphic Novels for Mo Willems Fans
item.description: Twelve recommendations for young fans of Mo Willems.
item.dc:creator: Travis Jonker
item.category: Dont Let the Pigeon Drive the Bus! (Book)
Lone Wolf Goes to the Library (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘A World Appears,’ by Michael Pollan
item.description: “A World Appears” explores what makes you you.
item.dc:creator: David Eagleman
item.category: A World Appears: A Journey Into Consciousness (Book)
item.media:credit: Cig Harvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Can plants be sentient? This is juts one facet of the nature of consciousness tackled by Michael Pollan in “A World Appears.”

item.title: Book Club: Read ‘Kin,’ by Tayari Jones, With the Book Review
item.description: In March, the Book Review Book Club will read and discuss Tayari Jones’s new novel, about two motherless girls and their lifelong search for family.
item.dc:creator: MJ Franklin

item.title: The 10 Best Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s top fiction and nonfiction.
item.category: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny (Book)
There Is No Place for Us: Working and Homeless in America (Book)
Mother Emanuel: Two Centuries of Race, Resistance, and Forgiveness in One Charleston Church (Book)
A Marriage at Sea: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck (Book)
Wild Thing: A Life of Paul Gauguin (Book)

item.title: Christina Applegate’s New Memoir Is Furious, Funny and Profane
item.description: Funny, furious and profane, “You With the Sad Eyes” finds the TV star facing childhood trauma and reflecting on the limits imposed by illness.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: John Shearer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Though she has retired from acting, Christina Applegate (here in front of her home) appeared onstage at the Emmy Awards in 2024.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Disappearing Act,’ by Maria Stepanova
item.description: In Maria Stepanova’s novel “The Disappearing Act,” an accidental stopover in a foreign town leads to personal change.
item.dc:creator: John Self

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Violet Hour,’ by James Cahill
item.description: James Cahill’s “The Violet Hour” contrasts the artifice of blue-chip modern art with the messy personal lives of the people who create and consume it.
item.dc:creator: Jay McInerney

item.title: Thrilling Slasher Books for ‘Scream’ and Horror Fans
item.description: These 13 bloodthirsty tales will keep you up at night with clever thrills and heart-pounding action.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Graham Jones
item.media:credit: Author photo by Alina Art

item.title: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘Wuthering Heights’
item.description: Emily Brontë’s classic Gothic romance is the basis for a new movie. It’s also more bonkers than you remember.
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Inset cover: via Penguin Books

item.title: 27 New Books to Read in March: Tana French, Liza Minnelli, Cat Sebastian and More
item.description: Novels by Tana French, Yann Martel and Cat Sebastian; memoirs by Christina Applegate and Liza Minnelli; a Judy Blume biography and more.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: 7 New Books Our Editors Love This Week
item.description: Reading recommendations from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: Young Man in a Hurry: A Memoir of Discovery (Book)

item.title: Teresa de Lauretis, Coiner (and Critic) of Queer Theory, Dies at 87
item.description: She came up with the term as the title of a 1990 conference but saw its later popularity as a little superficial.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Claudia Peppel
item.media:description: Teresa de Lauretis in 2015. The debut of “queer theory” as a term came in the title of an academic conference she organized and in an associated issue of a feminist journal.

item.title: Rose Lesniak, Poet Who Rescued Children and Trained Dogs, Dies at 70
item.description: A magnetic personality, she reinvented herself twice, bringing the same spirit to investigating child abuse and communing with dogs that she did to writing poetry.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Melissa Auf der Maur, a ’90s Rock Linchpin, Is Spilling Her Stories
item.description: The bassist and photographer who logged time in Hole and Smashing Pumpkins unpacks one of the most creative and chaotic times of her life in a new memoir.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Lucia Bell-Epstein
item.category: Even the Good Girls Will Cry: A '90s Rock Memoir (Book)
item.media:credit: Lucia Bell-Epstein for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: ‘Fashioning the Crown,’ by Justine Picardie
item.description: In a new book, the biographer Justine Picardie romps through a century of royal wardrobes.
item.dc:creator: Eva Wolchover
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Bettmann, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Although Wallis Simpson’s marital status may have been the official objection, she and Edward VIII had also scandalized courtiers with their jaunty sportswear.

item.title: Ann Godoff, a Top Editor and Publisher of Best Sellers, Dies at 76
item.description: Considered an “author’s publisher” at Random House and then Penguin, she cultivated the careers of dozens of celebrated novelists and nonfiction writers.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Librado Romero/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ann Godoff at the Random House offices in Manhattan in 1999 with the editor Robert Loomis. She had “a flawless sense of what would sell and what wouldn’t,” the biographer Ron Chernow said.

item.title: Writers Are Being Targeted by Scams. This Reporter Knows the Feeling.
item.description: From George Saunders to the National Book Foundation, the literary world has been besieged by fake requests. Just like me.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry

item.title: Book Review: ‘Starry and Restless,’ by Julia Cooke
item.description: “Starry and Restless,” by Julia Cooke, delivers an immersive account of the pathbreaking careers of Rebecca West, Martha Gellhorn and Emily Hahn.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: Starry and Restless: Three Women Who Changed Work, Writing, and the World (Book)
item.media:credit: From left: Dominique Berretty/Gamma-Rapho via Getty Images; FPG/Archive Photos, via Getty Images; Hulton-Deutsch Collection/Corbis via Getty Images

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry’ Author Says Parkinson’s Symptoms Are Worsening and Delays Book
item.description: Rachel Reid told fans that the disease’s progression was slowing her writing and that a much-anticipated follow-up book would be pushed back.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Carolina Andrade for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reid published in 2018 the first novel in the series, “Game Changer,” about a closeted hockey player who fell in love with a barista.

item.title: The Book Review: Director Clint Bentley on Adapting ‘Train Dreams’ for the Big Screen
item.description: The Oscar-nominated filmmaker talks about the daunting task of adapting Denis Johnson’s enigmatic novella
item.dc:creator: Gilbert Cruz, Sarah Diamond, Amy Pearl and Larissa Anderson
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Emma Mcintyre/Getty Images For SCAD

item.title: Book Review: ‘I Give You My Silence,’ by Mario Vargas Llosa
item.description: The final novel from a titan of Latin American literature follows a critic trying to capture the essence of his national culture.
item.dc:creator: Michael Greenberg

item.title: International Booker Prize Nominees: 13 Books to Get You Talking
item.description: Novels by Daniel Kehlmann, Olga Ravn and Gabriela Cabezón Cámara are among the 13 titles nominated for the renowned award for fiction translated into English.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: How Bookbinders Helped the Nazis Track Holocaust Victims
item.description: Conservation experts helped the Nazi regime inspect church and civil archives to track down people they sought to persecute, a researcher concluded.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Book Review: ‘Red Dawn Over China,’ by Frank Dikötter
item.description: In “Red Dawn Over China,” the historian Frank Dikötter shows that Communism’s rise in China was an unlikely, violent event with a lot of outside help.
item.dc:creator: Gary J. Bass
item.category: Red Dawn Over China: How Communism Conquered a Quarter of Humanity (Book)
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists visiting Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 2025.

item.title: Book Review: ‘More Than Enough,’ by Anna Quindlen
item.description: “More Than Enough” traces the struggles of a New York City private-school teacher, often through rose-tinted glasses.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Weiner

item.title: Anne Frank’s Love for Classical Music L Her Diary
item.description: Her diary overflows with her devotion to books and movies. But after rereading the entries, a critic was struck by how often she writes about music.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Tommasini
item.media:credit: Photo 12/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

item.title: Book Review: ‘Young Man in a Hurry,’ by Gavin Newsom
item.description: The new book by the California governor and undeclared presidential hopeful depicts a man shaped as much by hardship and struggle as privilege.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Young Man in a Hurry: A Memoir of Discovery (Book)
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gavin Newsom, then mayor of San Francisco, introduces Hillary Clinton, then a presidential candidate, seen here with the actors Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen, at a local fund-raiser in 2008.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Mixed Marriage Project,’ by Dorothy Roberts
item.description: In “The Mixed Marriage Project,” Dorothy Roberts reflects on her anthropologist father’s lifelong project: to document — and promote — interracial marriages like his own.
item.dc:creator: Julia Scheeres
item.category: The Mixed Marriage Project: A Memoir of Love, Race, and Family (Book)

item.title: A Wake for The Washington Post’s Book World
item.description: Literary and cultural denizens of the nation’s capital gathered on Saturday to eulogize The Post’s scuppered Book World supplement.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Dirda, a longtime book critic at The Washington Post, honors the paper’s books section, which was shuttered earlier this month amid widespread layoffs.

item.title: Edward Hoagland, Literary Explorer of Nature and Himself, Dies at 93
item.description: In his lyrical writings, he examined physical landscapes as well as the interior terrain of his own life — up to the blindness that overtook him in his later years.
item.dc:creator: Margalit Fox
item.media:credit: Oscar White/Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Edward Hoagland, best known for writing about the natural world, travel and his own life, was, John Updike said, “the best essayist of my generation.”

item.title: Book Review: ‘White River Crossing,’ by Ian McGuire
item.description: Ian McGuire’s new novel, “White River Crossing,” tracks a party of 18th-century fortune seekers through the northern Canadian wilds.
item.dc:creator: Laird Hunt

item.title: Susan Sheehan, Pulitzer-Winning Chronicler of Lives on the Margins, Dies at 88
item.description: As a journalist and author, she wrote meticulous portraits of people for The New Yorker. Her book “Is There No Place on Earth for Me?” won the Pulitzer Prize.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: Is There No Place on Earth for Me? (Book)
item.media:credit: George Tames/The New York Times
item.media:description: Susan Sheehan in 1982 at her home in Washington.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Brawler,’ by Lauren Groff
item.description: The best stories in “Brawler” find the writer tackling the tectonic shifts that can suddenly crack open seemingly secure families.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.media:credit: Dustin Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I became a writer because I was a swimmer,” Lauren Groff explains to readers in a note at the end of her story collection “Brawler.”

item.title: New Historical Fiction Books
item.description: Our columnist on four stellar new releases.
item.dc:creator: Alida Becker

item.title: Lisa Rinna Tells All in New Memoir, Including ‘Real Housewives’ and More
item.description: The outrageous reality TV star has written a memoir — part evolution, part exorcism. She’s more than ready to tell you why.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.category: The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Ariel Fisher for The New York Times
